query: Count contracts by governing law state with clauses

result.cypher: MATCH (c:Contract)-[:CONTAINS]->(cl:Clause)-[:OF_TYPE]->(ct:ClauseType) WHERE ct.name = 'Governing Law' AND (cl.text =~ '(?i).*California.*' OR cl.text =~ '(?i).*New York.*' OR cl.text =~ '(?i).*Delaware.*') WITH CASE WHEN cl.text =~ '(?i).*California.*' THEN 'California' WHEN cl.text =~ '(?i).*New York.*' THEN 'New York' WHEN cl.text =~ '(?i).*Delaware.*' THEN 'Delaware' ELSE 'Other' END as state, c, cl, ct WITH state, count(DISTINCT c) as contract_count, collect({contract: c, clause: cl, clauseType: ct})[0..10] as sample_data UNWIND sample_data as data RETURN state, contract_count, data.contract.id as c_id, data.contract.title as c_title, data.contract.num_clauses as c_num_clauses, data.contract.context as c_context, data.clause.id as cl_id, data.clause.text as cl_text, data.clauseType.name as ct_name ORDER BY state, contract_count DESC LIMIT 50

analysis.summary: The query results provide both aggregated counts and detailed contract information for contracts governed by the laws of California, New York, and Delaware. California has 46 contracts, Delaware has 37, and New York has 78. Detailed clauses from specific contracts are also available, showcasing the dual capability of GraphRAG to provide both summary statistics and detailed contract/clause information in a single query.
insights: New York is the most common governing law state among the contracts analyzed, indicating a preference or strategic advantage for businesses operating under New York law.
The availability of detailed clauses allows for a deeper understanding of specific legal language and potential implications in each jurisdiction.

GraphRAG's dual capability to provide both aggregated counts and detailed contract/clause information enables comprehensive analysis in a single query, unlike traditional RAG which cannot aggregate or combine summary and detail data.
riskFlags: High concentration of contracts under New York law may expose businesses to specific legal risks associated with that jurisdiction.
recommendations: Consider diversifying the governing law clauses to mitigate jurisdiction-specific risks.
Leverage the detailed clause information to ensure compliance and alignment with business objectives in each jurisdiction.
